Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark REM SURFACE ENGINEERING & Design is deceptively misdescriptive or distinctive under s. 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Board focused only on visual aspects; court emphasized 'when sounded' test
Decision_Outcome: Trademark found unregistrable due to deceptive misdescription and lack of distinctiveness
Legal_Rule: A trademark is unregistrable if it is clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive of the character, quality, or production of goods/services when depicted, written, or sounded
Procedural_Issue: Failure of the Board to consider auditory perception ('when sounded')
Grounds_for_Claim: Deceptive misdescription regarding implication of licensed engineering services in Canada
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark is deceptively misdescriptive and not distinctive
Decision_Maker: Trademarks Opposition Board (initial), Federal Court (on appeal)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Board's analysis deemed incomplete for ignoring phonetic component
Key_Evidence_Considered: Visual design elements, phonetic pronunciation of 'REM SURFACE ENGINEERING'
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, registrability criteria under Trade-marks Act
Applicant_Challenge: Registration opposed on grounds of deceptive misdescription
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Boardâ€™s decision permitting registration
Legal_Provision: s. 12(1)(b), s. 56(1) of the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Deceptive misdescription implying professional engineering services
Applicable_Process: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
